messages.message: The PowerSpecifications/AC/Description child element shall describe the ac power. This description may include such items as three-phase configurations (delta or wye), electromagnetic interference and electromagnetic compatibility (EMI/EMC) characteristics, etc.
The dimensionless number of phases to the ac power form. The default shall be 1. Example: 3 (indicating a three-phase ac requirement that is either a delta or a wye configuration).
The PowerSpecifications/AC/ConnectorPins child element shall identify the ac power connector pins.
Segmented Source File are .....
A string that permits the instrument’s default address to be indicated. Example: “255” (for VXI dynamic addressing)
A Cache with the name \"{0}\" does not exist
The Item/Description child element shall be a description of the hardware item.
A descriptive or common name for the hardware item.
Delete port \"{0}"?
The DatumQuality/Confidence child element shall contain the required confidence.
Any nonstandard unit not already defined in IEEE Std 260.1
When used, this attribute shall contain only a unit of measure defined in IEEE Std 260.1
A textual qualifier that is to be applied to the attribute of either the standardUnit or nonStandardUnit. Examples: RMS or Peak-to-Peak for a standardUnit of volts.
The DatumQuality/Resolution child element shall contain the required resolution.
A user-defined string uniquely identifying the subassembly. Example: Pre-Amp A1.
A user-defined string uniquely identifying the connector. Example: J1.
A descriptive or common name of where the connector is located. Example: Front Panel.
A descriptive or common name for the mating connector. Example: The mating connector for a 15-pin d-shell connector (male) is a 15-pin d-shell connector (female).
A descriptive or common name for the mating connector. Example: The mating connector for a 15-pin d-shell connector (male) is a 15-pin d-shell connector (female).
A selectable list of different pin configurations for the selected connector type.
The number of pins the connector has. This number will be used to create empty Connector Pins.
The number of pins contained within the connector.
A descriptive or common name for the type of connector. Example: MIL-C-38999.
A user-defined string uniquely identifying the connector.
A user-defined string uniquely identifying the pin within the connector.
Starting index for the items.
Number of identical items.
A user-defined string uniquely identifying the connector pin.
Specifies the value by which the items are to be incremented.
A descriptive or common name for the connector pin.
Specifies the character replacement in association with the calculated index.
The Generic complex type shall be the base type for XML schema elements intended to identify the document that contains the instrument’s generic control language specification.
The Register complex type shall be the base type for XML schema child elements intended to identify the document that contains the instrument’s register commands.
The SCPI complex type shall be the base type for XML schema elements intended to identify the document that contains the instrument’s SCPI commands.
Select the base type for the Control Language.
The number of matrix lines available to connect the rows and columns.
Cross Point Switch Ports for the Rows and Columns.
The DatumQuality/Confidence child element shall contain the required confidence.
The DatumType complex type shall be the base type for XML schema elements that contain a numeric, boolean, string, or a date-time data value, each with an optional unit.
The DatumQuality/Resolution child element shall contain the required resolution.
The PowerSpecifications/DC/Description child element shall describe the dc power.
An indication of the polarity of the dc voltage with respect to ground. Examples: positive and negative.
The ac component of the dc voltage.
A unique identifier for the document.
A textual description of the document.
A descriptive or common name for the document
Either the document text or the URL where the document may be accessed.
The universal unique identifier for the document.
The version identification of the document.
A user-defined string uniquely identifying the document.
The universal unique identifier for the document.
The minimum storage capacity needed to store the software driver and permit its execution. Example: 6 GB.
The minimum physical memory capacity needed for the software driver to execute. Example: 512 MB.
The OperatingSystem child element shall identify computer operating system requirements needed in order for the driver to execute.
The minimum clock speed of the processor required for the software driver to execute. Example: 10 GHz or greater Acme-3 processor.
The operating system’s service pack identification. Example: Service Pack 1.1.
The EnvironmentalElements/Altitude child element shall contain an altitude value.
The EnvironmentalElements/Humidity child element shall contain the relative humidity value.
The EnvironmentalElements/Shock child element shall contain the physical shock value.
The EnvironmentalElements/Temperature child element shall contain the temperature value.
The EnvironmentalElements/Vibration/Displacement child element shall contain the displacement (the amplitude of a point on the item) value.
The EnvironmentalElements/Vibration/Frequency child element shall contain the natural resonance frequency value.
The EnvironmentalElements/Vibration/Velocity child element shall contain the acceleration (rate of change of velocity of a point in an item) value.
The HardwareItemDescription/Errors/Error/Description child element shall provide a description of the error associated with the hardware item.
A user-defined string uniquely identifying the error. Example: built-in test (BIT) #5 failure.
A descriptive or common name for the source of the error. Example: Power-up BIT.
The severity of the error. Example: Fatal.
Check to indication as to whether the instrument’s Ethernet interface supports the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCPv4 Specification RFC 4361 [B3])
Error: Could not read file from disk. Original error: {0}
Are you sure you want to delete {0} "{1}?"
V E R I F I C A T I O N
An indication of how often calibration shall be performed. Y: Year, M:Month, D:Day, H:Hour, m:Minute, s:Second
The warm-up time of the hardware item.
An alphanumeric string that identifies an item within a larger assembly. For example, a reference designator such as A25 to indicate a circuit card number.
The model name of the item.
A string designating the version of the described item.
A descriptive or common name for the manufacturer. (Required only for a Manufacturer Identification type)
Identification Number

An adjective providing additional descriptive data that further specify or identify the ‘number’ attribute. Example: the identification number specified by the User. (Required only for a User Identification type)
An indication of whether the c:IdentificationNumber is a part number, model number, or other.
/inst:InstrumentDescription/inst:Capabilities/hc:Capability[@name="{0}"]/hc:Interface/c:Ports/c:Port[@name="{1}"]
/inst:InstrumentDescription/inst:Resources/hc:Resource[@name="{0}"]/hc:Interface/c:Ports/c:Port[@name="{1}"]
A descriptive or common nomen for the described item.

Used to describe the type of instrument. It may be one of the following values:
Module Instrument Option
Universally Unique Identifier for the Instrument Description.
A string designating the version of the described item.
A detailed description of the item.
A descriptive or common name for the item.
The ItemDescription/Description child element shall contain a free-form textual description of the item described.
A descriptive or common name for the described item.
A string designating the version of the described item.
A descriptive or common name for the document

The comparison with the two boundary limits may be for a value between the limits or outside the limits. The LogicalOperator AND explicitly indicates a between comparison; OR explicitly indicates an outside comparison. Example: GT 3 AND LT 7 (between) vs. GT 10 OR LT 3 (outside). While the logical operator may be inferred from the combination of limit values and comparison types, the LogicalOperator attribute permits better definition and less possibility for misinterpretation.
When used, this attribute shall contain only a unit of measure defined in IEEE Std 260.1
The actual value of the data.
The Limit/Description child element shall contain a textual description of the limit being described.
Selection for the Type of Limit: Expected, Single Limit, Limit Pair or Mask.
A descriptive or common name for the limit expressed in the element.

The comparison with the two boundary limits may be for a value between the limits or outside the limits. The LogicalOperator AND explicitly indicates a between comparison; OR explicitly indicates an outside comparison. Example: GT 3 AND LT 7 (between) vs. GT 10 OR LT 3 or GT 5 OR GT 10 (outside). While the logical operator may be inferred from the combination of limit values and comparison types, the c:LogicalOperator attribute permits better definition and less possibility for misinterpretation.
A means to add a limit quickly byt typing in a shorthand notation. (ex. 3V to 5V)
A descriptive or common name for the limit pair expressed in the element
The LimitPair/Nominal child element shall contain the expected or preferred value to be captured.

The comparison with the two boundary limits may be for a value between the limits or outside the limits. The LogicalOperator AND explicitly indicates a between comparison; OR explicitly indicates an outside comparison. Example: GT 3 AND LT 7 (between) vs. GT 10 OR LT 3 (outside). While the logical operator may be inferred from the combination of limit values and comparison types, the LogicalOperator attribute permits better definition and less possibility for misinterpretation.
The data type of the value.
The LXI class. The allowable classes are: A, B, or C.
A string that permits the LXI version to be indicated. Example: “1.2.01”
The ManufacturerData complex type shall be the base type for any XML schema element that is intended to contain information identifying the manufacturer of an item.

The textual description of the physical street address. The second line is for textual description of additional street address information (e.g., suite number, mail stop) that shall be associated with Address1.
The commercial and government entity (CAGE) code for the company indicated by the name attribute.
The textual description of the city.
All the contacts assiciated with the manufacturer.
The manufacturer's country.
The textual representation of the facsimile telephone number of the manufacturer.
Check if the Manufacturer has an address
The textual representation of the postal mailing address of the manufacturer
A descriptive or common name for the manufacturer.
The postal/zip code code for the manufacturer.
The URL of the Web site for the manufacturer.
The email address for the contact.
The contact’s given name. (Required)
The contact’s telephone number.
Pin Descriptions for the Matrix Switch Rows and Columns.
A descriptive or common name for the subject data value.
Starting index for the items.
Number of identical items.
The Network/Description child element shall provide a description of the network connection.

Specifies the value to increment by when calculating the value with which the replacement character is replaced. Allows for defining items where paired items have different characteristics. Defaults to 1.
The NetworkNode complex type shall be the base type for XML schema elements intended to document properties of the network node to which the hardware item is connected.
Character replaced with calculated index when repeated items are expanded.
The NetworkNode/Path child element describes the XPath expression that shall evaluate to a single node. This single node is part of the path.
The UUID for the document referenced by the element.
The NetworkNode/Description child element shall describe the network node to which the hardware item is connected.
The NetworkNode/Path child element describes the XPath expression that shall evaluate to a single node. This single node is part of the path.
The identification of the particular instrument. This identifier (ID) is allocated by the vendor.
The identification of the manufacturer of the instrument. Valid vendor IDs are allocated by the PCI Special Interest Group (PCI-SIG) to ensure uniqueness.
The PhysicalCharacteristics/Mass child element shall identify the mass of the subject hardware item.
The PhysicalCharacteristics/Volume child element shall identify the physical volume of the subject hardware item.
The PhysicalCharacteristics/LinearMeasurements/RackUSize child element shall identify the rack unit size of the subject hardware item.
Select the rack size units to enter. If you select anything other than "Rack Units", the Rack Unit value will be calculated for you.
The PhysicalCharacteristics/LinearMeasurements/Depth child element shall identify the lineal depth measurement of the subject hardware item.
The PhysicalCharacteristics/LinearMeasurements/Height child element shall identify the lineal height measurement of the subject hardware item.
The RackUSize child element shall identify the rack unit size of the subject hardware item in inches.
The RackUSize child element shall identify the rack unit size of the subject hardware item in millimeters.
The RackUSize child element shall identify the rack unit size of the subject hardware item.
The PhysicalCharacteristics/LinearMeasurements/Width child element shall identify the lineal width measurement of the subject hardware item.
An enumeration providing for the specification of the direction in which data moves on the described port. Enumeration values are Input, Output, and Bi-Directional.
A descriptive or common name for the port. (Required)
An enumeration providing for the specification of the type of the described port. Enumeration values are Ground, Analog, Digital, Power, Optical, or Software.
The amount of current on the –12 line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
The amount of current on the +12 line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
The amount of current on the +3.3 line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
The amount of current on the +5 line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
Starting index for the items.
Number of identical items

Specifies the value to increment by when calculating the value with which the replacement character is replaced. Allows for defining items where paired items have different characteristics. Defaults to 1.
Character replaced with calculated index when repeated items are expanded.
The index of the element within an hc:RepeatedItem array.
An indication that the element is or is not classified. If the item is classified then the level of classification must be selected from the associated drop list.
A space delimited list of Ports that are used as inout parameters to this signal.
A nomen for this Signal.
The Signal Function Type selected to posess the signal value.
Space delimited list of sibling Signal Funtion Types used as input parameters to this Signal Function Type.
A string nomen for this Signal Function Type
The Specification/Description child element shall provide a short description in English of the specification.
A descriptive or common name for the specification. Example: Acme ABCD DMM Product Specifications.
Check to show that the device will accept a backplane clock.
Check to show that the device will accept an external clock.
Check if the device will accept an internal clock.
The SwitchPort/Pin child element shall identify a physical pin of a switch. Name: A descriptive or common name for the switch pin. Line: The number of lines available to connect the rows or columns.
The Switch/Connections/RelaySetting/RelayConnection child element shall identify a path established by the relay setting.
The manufacturer's state.
The amplitude of the trigger signal.
The units associated with the trigger signal amplitude. Either %FullScale or +/-V shall be specified.
The resolution of the trigger signal amplitude reading. An integer number shall be specified.
An identification of the digital edge that shall be present for the trigger to occur. The edge shall be Rising, Falling, or Selectable.
An identification of the digital level that shall be present for the trigger to occur. The level shall be High, Low, or Selectable.
The dimension associated with the pulse width’s value. Allowable dimensions shall be S, mS, uS, nS, pS, or fS.
The numeric value of the pulse width.
Describe the trigger signal.
A descriptive or common name for the signal that will generate the trigger.

Type of Trigger - Analog Trigger Property Group: properties of an analog based trigger; Digital Trigger Property Group: properties of a digial based trigger; LAN Trigger Property Group: properties of a local area network based trigger; Software Trigger Property Group: properties of a trigger initiated by software.
The Trigger/Description child element shall provide an accurate description of what the trigger signal is (e.g., electrically, in time, what the trigger is based upon).
A descriptive or common name for the trigger.
A string that permits the name of the instance document to be indicated.
uuid is a universal unique identifier for the element containing this attribute.
A string that permits the version of the instance
The type of the value: Datum, Collection or Indexed Array
An identification of the version number.
A descriptive or common name for the version.
An indication of whether the version specified is the minimum or maximum.
Represents Module Cooling as air flow in liters/sec.
The module cooling as back pressure in mm/H2O
The amount of current on the –12 V line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
The amount of current on the –2 V line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
The amount of current on the –24 V line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
The amount of current on the –5.2 V line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
The amount of current on the +12 V line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
The amount of current on the +24 V line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
The amount of current on the +5 V line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”
The amount of current on the +5 V standby line. A positive value means the device provides current. A negative value means the device consumes current. Example: “–0.5”

An integer representing the keying class (1 through 6) defined by VXI-1, Figure B.28 [B25]Classes 7, 8, and 9 are defined as follows:Class 7 = No local busClass 8 = Sensor ±16 VClass 9 = Sensor ±42 VBottom key supports D size modules. Bottom key on C size modules shall be specified as 7.

An integer representing the keying class (1 through 6) defined by the VXI-1, Figure B.28 [B25]Classes 7, 8, and 9 are defined as follows:Class 7 = No local busClass 8 = Sensor ±16 VClass 9 = Sensor ±42 VBottom key supports D size modules. Bottom key on C size modules shall be specified as 7.

An integer representing the keying class (1 through 6) defined by VXI-1, Figure B.28 [B25]Classes 7, 8, and 9 are defined as follows:Class 7 = No local busClass 8 = Sensor ±16 VClass 9 = Sensor ±42 VTop key supports C size modules only.

An integer representing the keying class (1 through 6) defined by VXI-1, Figure B.28 [B25]Classes 7, 8, and 9 are defined as follows:Class 7 = No local busClass 8 = Sensor ±16 VClass 9 = Sensor ±42 VTop key supports C size modules only.
The Driver complex type shall be the base type for XML schema elements intended to document instrument drivers.
The prefix to be used for all API functions in the VPP driver.
A descriptive or common computer-based name for the driver.
A descriptive or common computer-based path to the directory where the driver is installed.

IVI-C: A complex type shall be the base type for XML schema elements intended to document properties of an IVI C language (IVI-C) driver.
IVI-COM: A complex type shall be the base type for XML schema elements intended to document properties of an IVI component object module (IVI-COM) driver.
IVI.NET: A complex type shall be the base type for XML schema elements intended to document properties of an IVI.NET driver.
VPP: A complex type shall be the base type for XML schema elements intended to document properties of a VMEbus extensions for instrumentation (VXI) plug and play (VPP) driver.
The location of the software tool, within the operating system structure, on the hard disk.
The HardwareItemDescription/Control/Tools/Tool/Dependencies child element shall identify a tool’s software and/or driver dependencies.
identify a tool’s software or driver dependencies.
The Controller/Processor/Architecture child element shall identify the architecture of the processor (e.g., 8086).
The Controller/Processor/Type child element shall identify the type of processor (e.g., PentiumM, PowerPC).
The Controller/Processor/Quantity child element shall identify the number of processors.
The Controller/Processor/Speed child element shall identify the processor’s clock speed.
The Controller/PhysicalMemory child element shall identify the physical memory of the controller.
The Controller/OperatingSystems/OperatingSystem/OperatingSystemUpdates child element shall identify all operating system updates installed on the controller.
A descriptive or common name for the disk drive. Examples: External Optical and CDROM.
A Yes or No indication (1 or 0) of whether this disk drive serves as the controller’s boot drive.
The Controller/Storage/Drive/Size child element shall identify the disk drive’s storage capacity.
The FacilitiesRequirements/Cooling child element shall identify any cooling requirements of the hardware item.
The FacilitiesRequirements/Hydraulic child element shall identify hydraulic requirements of the hardware item.
The FacilitiesRequirements/Pneumatic child element shall identify pneumatic requirements of the hardware item.
A descriptive or common name for the described Test Station.
A string designating the version of the described Test Station.
The PowerSpecifications/DC/ConnectorPins/ConnectorPin child element shall identify the dc power connector pins.
A descriptive or common name for the hardware item.
The Item/Description child element shall be a description of the hardware item.
